Introduction

Diuresis refers to increased urine production, regardless of urine composition.  The term natriuresis more specifically describes an increase in urinary sodium excretion.  Most diuretic medications induce natriuresis, leading to diuresis because water follows sodium into the urine.  An exception is vasopressin receptor antagonists, which promote pure water diuresis without sodium excretion (aquaresis).  This article focuses on the different classes of diuretics, their mechanisms of action, adverse effects, and clinical applications.

Classes of diuretics



Diuretics are classified based on their site of action within the nephron and their mechanism of action (

figure 1
).  The different classes are discussed below and summarized in this table (

).

Loop diuretics



Loop diuretics (eg, furosemide, torsemide, bumetanide, ethacrynic acid) are the most potent class.  They work by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Clâˆ’ cotransporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle.  This nephron segment is responsible for most Na+ reabsorption, with approximately 20%-25% of filtered Na+ occurring here.  By blocking this, loop diuretics lead to significant urinary Na+ loss (natriuresis).



The loop of Henle also plays a crucial role in maintaining the medullary concentration gradient, allowing the kidneys to concentrate urine.  The thick ascending limb is impermeable to water but actively transports Na+, K+, and Clâˆ’ into the medullary interstitium, increasing its osmolarity.  This high osmolarity enables water reabsorption in the descending limb and collecting ducts (under the influence of antidiuretic hormone [ADH]).  By inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Clâˆ’ cotransporter, loop diuretics reduce ion transport into the medullary interstitium, diminishing the osmotic gradient and impairing water reabsorption.  The combination of increased sodium loss and reduced water reabsorption leads to robust diuresis.



Because loop diuretics are highly protein-bound, they enter the renal tubules predominantly via secretion rather than filtration.  This allows them to remain effective in patients with a significantly reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR) (chronic kidney disease [CKD]).  Adverse effects include the following:



  • Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia
  • Hypovolemia, hypotension, and acute kidney injury (AKI)
  • Metabolic alkalosis (mainly due to chloride depletion) and hyperuricemia (predisposing to gout)
  • Ototoxicity, especially at high doses or with rapid intravenous (IV) administration
  • Hypersensitivity reactions to sulfonamides (ethacrynic acid (
    figure 2
    ) is used instead).  Notably, patients allergic to sulfonamide antibiotics can generally still receive loop diuretics due to their lack of cross-reactivity.

Thiazides and thiazide-like diuretics



Thiazides and thiazide-like diuretics (eg, hydrochlorothiazide, chlorthalidone, metolazone, indapamide) inhibit the Na+-Clâˆ’ cotransporter in the distal convoluted tubule.  This segment reabsorbs significantly less Na+ than the loop of Henle, so thiazides excrete only 3%-5% of filtered Na+, making them less effective than loop diuretics.  In addition, they increase calcium reabsorption (

figure 3
), in contrast to loop diuretics.  Thiazides are much less protein-bound than loop diuretics and are therefore largely dependent on glomerular filtration; as such, they are less effective in patients with advanced CKD (GFR <30 mL/min).  Adverse effects include the following:



  • Hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and metabolic alkalosis (less profound than loop diuretics)
  • Mild hypercalcemia, especially in patients with primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Hyponatremia (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
    ), most commonly seen in elderly female patients with a low BMI (often due to increased water intake and retention)
  • Mild hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia, although clinically insignificant compared to antihypertensive benefits

Potassium-sparing diuretics



Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRAs) (eg, spironolactone, eplerenone, finerenone) and epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) blockers (eg, amiloride, triamterene) inhibit Na+ reabsorption at the most distal nephron site, the collecting duct.  MRAs specifically block the aldosterone receptor, reducing activity of the apical ENaC channel and basolateral Na-K-ATPase, whereas ENaC blockers directly inhibit the Na+ channels.



Because most Na+ reabsorption has already occurred more proximally, these diuretics are weak, excreting only 1%-2% of filtered Na+.  However, they are very effective in promoting K+ retention due to their ability to inhibit K+ secretion (hence the name potassium-sparing diuretics) (

figure 4
).  Adverse effects include the following:



  • Hyperkalemia may occur, particularly in patients also taking an ACE inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB).
  • Metabolic acidosis due to less K+ in the tubules, which reduces electronegativity and impairs acid excretion.  Acidosis is more pronounced with MRAs due to the additional inhibition of H+-ATPse.
  • Spironolactone can cause gynecomastia and sexual dysfunction by also binding androgen receptors (not seen with eplerenone).


When combined with loop diuretics or thiazides, potassium-sparing diuretics can help counteract the potassium loss and metabolic alkalosis induced by the other agents, helping to maintain normal serum potassium and bicarbonate levels.

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors



Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (eg, acetazolamide) act by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase in the proximal tubule, reducing bicarbonate reabsorption (

figure 5
).  Bicarbonate normally binds to filtered Na+, and although the proximal tubule normally reabsorbs the majority of filtered Na+, blocking this process does not cause significant diuresis.  This is because Na+ is simply reabsorbed in more distal parts of the nephron.  Therefore, carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are not used for managing volume overload but are more commonly used to counteract diuretic-induced metabolic alkalosis.  In addition to metabolic acidosis, the major adverse effect is an increased risk for nephrolithiasis (ie, increased urine pH promotes calcium phosphate formation).



The use in conditions such as altitude sickness, glaucoma, and benign idiopathic intracranial hypertension is distinct from their diuretic effects (discussed in separate articles).

Osmotic diuretics



Osmotic diuretics (eg, mannitol) increase the osmolarity of the filtrate, primarily in the proximal tubule and descending loop of Henle.  This limits water reabsorption, leading to diuresis.  Unlike other classes, osmotic diuretics do not directly affect electrolyte transport.  However, retained water in the tubules indirectly promotes excretion of Na+ and other electrolytes.  Although effective at increasing urine volume, this class is not used for routine diuresis due to the lack of specific Na+ modulation and the potential for transiently increasing intravascular volume in patients with heart failure (before the mannitol is filtered by the kidneys).  Instead, they are used for other purposes, such as managing elevated intracranial pressure and glaucoma.

Vasopressin receptor antagonists



Vasopressin receptor antagonists, commonly referred to as "vaptans," include tolvaptan (oral) or conivaptan (IV).  These medications block vasopressin (ADH) at the V2 aquaporin receptors in the collecting ducts.  Normally, ADH promotes water reabsorption by increasing the number of aquaporin channels.  By inhibiting this action, vaptans promote pure water excretion without Na+ loss, thereby increasing serum Na+ concentration.  As such, vaptans cause aquaresis rather than natriuresis and are therefore used to treat water overload seen in hyponatremia (eg, syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion) rather than volume overload.  Major adverse effects include liver toxicity with prolonged use (particularly with tolvaptan) and the risk for osmotic demyelination syndrome if hyponatremia is corrected too rapidly.

Clinical applications

Heart failure



Loop diuretics are the primary agents for managing volume overload in heart failure due to their strong natriuretic effect.  For resistant edema, typically seen in advanced disease, thiazides may be added.  Dietary salt intake should also be limited for the following reasons:



  • Diuretic efficacy:  High salt intake decreases diuretic effectiveness.  Increased dietary sodium leads to greater filtered sodium, potentially overwhelming the diuretic's capacity to promote sodium excretion.
  • Compensatory mechanisms:  Diuretic-induced volume loss activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), promoting sodium retention.  A high-sodium diet exacerbates this maladaptive response, further reducing diuretic efficacy.


Potassium-sparing diuretics (eg, MRAs) can be added to help offset diuretic-induced hypokalemia and may provide the added benefits of mildly enhancing diuresis and lowering blood pressure.  Furthermore, MRAs specifically improve long-term survival in heart failure with an ejection fraction <35% by helping reverse aldosterone-mediated left ventricular remodeling.

Hypertension and CKD



Thiazides are a first-line option for hypertension in most patients, with chlorthalidone showing the greatest efficacy.  Beyond their diuretic effect, thiazides may lower blood pressure by inducing peripheral vasodilation (eg, opening vascular K+ channels).  As GFR decreases, thiazides become less effective because their delivery to the site of action in the renal tubules is impaired.  In advanced CKD (GFR <30 mL/min), loop diuretics are the preferred diuretic for managing blood pressure and volume overload.

Nephrotic syndrome



Loop diuretics are the mainstay of edema management in nephrotic syndrome, often requiring high doses to overcome the reduced efficacy caused by hypoalbuminemia (loop diuretics are highly protein-bound).  For persistent edema, combination therapy with thiazides or potassium-sparing diuretics may be necessary to achieve adequate diuresis by targeting different nephron segments.  In addition, strict dietary salt restriction is essential to optimize the diuretic response and minimize fluid retention.

Cirrhosis



MRAs (eg, spironolactone) are first-line therapy for managing volume overload in cirrhosis due to their ability to block aldosterone, which is markedly elevated in this condition (due to RAAS hyperactivity).  Loop diuretics (eg, furosemide) are typically added as adjunctive therapy to enhance diuresis and maintain normal serum K+ (when given in a standard ratio [eg, 40 mg furosemide:100 mg spironolactone]).  Dietary salt restriction is of paramount importance given the extreme avidity for sodium that is seen in cirrhosis.

Metabolic disorders



Loop diuretics are used to promote calcium excretion in the management of hypercalcemia.  Conversely, thiazides should be avoided in hypercalcemia because they pull calcium from the urine into the blood.  As such, thiazides are a treatment option for patients with calcium-containing kidney stones to reduce urinary calcium excretion.  For acute hyperkalemia, both loop diuretics and thiazides can help promote potassium excretion, although they are typically reserved for patients with concurrent volume overload.

Special considerations

Combination therapy



Combination diuretic therapy may be required when monotherapy fails to control volume overload.  Thiazides can be combined with loop diuretics to enhance diuresis by blocking sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule, compensating for the increased distal sodium delivery caused by loop diuretics.  This approach, known as sequential nephron blockade, is particularly effective in patients with resistant edema or heart failure.  In addition, potassium-sparing diuretics can be used alongside loop diuretics or thiazides to minimize the risk for hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

Diuretic resistance



Patients may develop a reduction or loss of diuretic effectiveness due to the following:



  • Increased sodium reabsorption in distal nephron segments (the "braking" phenomenon)
  • Worsening renal function (eg, reduced renal blood flow or impaired tubular secretion of the diuretic)
  • Decreased bioavailability, particularly with oral furosemide, which can have significantly impaired absorption in patients with gut edema


Mitigation strategies include increasing the diuretic dose and/or frequency, switching from oral to IV formulations (

figure 6
), or using sequential nephron blockade.  In severe cases, when conventional diuretics fail, ultrafiltration via dialysis may be required to remove excess fluid.

Drug interactions



Diuretics can interact with various medications, altering their efficacy or increasing the risk for adverse effects.



  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs):  By inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, NSAIDs reduce renal blood flow and GFR, which can result in reduced diuretic efficacy (particularly with loop diuretics) or lead to AKI.
  • ACE inhibitors or ARBs:  Combined with loop diuretics or thiazides, these medications increase the risk for AKI.  When used with potassium-sparing diuretics, they can increase the risk for hyperkalemia, especially in patients with CKD.
  • Digoxin:  In patients with heart failure who are taking loop diuretics, diuretic-induced hypokalemia increases the risk for digoxin toxicity by enhancing its binding to the cardiac Na-K-ATPase, predisposing to arrhythmias.
  • Lithium:  Thiazides and loop diuretics can increase lithium reabsorption in the proximal tubule, potentially causing lithium toxicity.

Diuretic misuse



Diuretics, particularly loop diuretics, may be misused by individuals with eating disorders attempting to lose weight.  This can lead to severe electrolyte imbalances, metabolic alkalosis, and AKI.

Summary



Diuretics are diverse medications that help in the management of a wide range of conditions, including heart failure, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and edema from various causes (eg, nephrotic syndrome, cirrhosis).  Each diuretic class works via distinct mechanisms within different parts of the nephron, resulting in varying effects on sodium and water excretion.  Although loop diuretics are the most potent and widely used for managing volume overload, thiazides are preferred for blood pressure control.  Potassium-sparing diuretics provide a valuable adjunct to counteract electrolyte imbalances, whereas osmotic diuretics and vasopressin receptor antagonists have more specialized uses.



Although generally effective and well-tolerated, diuretics can cause significant adverse effects, particularly electrolyte imbalances and metabolic disturbances.  Careful monitoring and appropriate dosing are necessary to minimize these risks.  In some cases, combination therapy may be required to enhance efficacy or mitigate adverse effects.  Challenges such as diuretic resistance may arise, requiring strategies like employing dose adjustment, switching to intravenous formulations, or using sequential nephron blockade.
